channel.title: Terror in the capital of peace (76? deaths)
channel.description:
Norway has been hit by twin attacks - a massive bomb blast in the capital and a shooting attack on young people at a governing Labour Party youth camp. At least seven people were killed in the bombing, which inflicted huge damage on government buildings in Oslo. At least 10 more died at the camp, on an island outside Oslo, police say. One witness said he had seen 20 bodies. Police arrested the suspected gunman at the camp and the government have confirmed that he is Norwegian. Prime Minister Jens Stoltenberg, whose Oslo offices were among those damaged by the bomb, described the attacks as "bloody and cowardly" in a news conference. He said that Norway had been "shaken by evil" but that Norwegian democracy and ideals would not be destroyed. [i]For more read the article[/i]
Since nobody posted it, I do. EDIT: Changed source from Fox News to BBC. Please don't start any gun laws discussions, it wouldn't change the event.

item.title: Terror in the capital of peace (76? deaths)
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

They don’t see it as justified, they see it as collateral damage. Of course its not justified, but they’re not intentionally doing it. Its “the price to pay for freedom” lel.

In other words, they aren’t trying to kill them, but they don’t care if they do.

Read full topic
item.source: Terror in the capital of peace (76? deaths)

item.title: Terror in the capital of peace (76? deaths)
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

Moparisthebest:

His ‘world view’ that innocent children should be blown up and gunned down? I’d certainly hope not.

Look at it from another perspective. Say… when women and children die from drone attacks in Pakistan? You’d expect most people would think it’s wrong. Yet the Whitehouse sees it perfectly justified.

Read full topic

item.title: Terror in the capital of peace (76? deaths)
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:153, topic:405764”]His ‘world view’ that innocent children should be blown up and gunned down? I’d certainly hope not.[/quote]First of all, he never blew up any children, he blew up a building as a distraction.

Secondly, in his view they were victims of war, just as civilians in Syria are victims of war from NATO bombings. The goal was to eliminate most potential candidates for the social democratic governments future in an attempt to have the right wing seize power.

I do not share his views, but i can certainly see the logic behind it.

Read full topic

The guy isn’t crazy though. He just did what he deemed necessary, how horrible it might be.
[/quote]
But it is not something a sane person would/should ever do, isn’t that the definition of crazy?[/quote]That would define every prisoner crazy and if every prisoner is crazy, then nobody would be in prison.

item.title: Terror in the capital of peace (76? deaths)
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:150, topic:405764”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=502755.msg3713685#msg3713685 date=1313505975]

The guy isn’t crazy though. He just did what he deemed necessary, how horrible it might be.

But it is not something a sane person would/should ever do, isn’t that the definition of crazy?
[/quote]Last time i checked, being crazy involved making hasty irrational decisions, neither of which would fit into Breiviks profile.

MITB is right, the definition of crazy could include Breivik because his view on the world is so different than rest of us.[/quote]Tons of people share his world view, the difference is that most of them aren’t willing to risk their freedom in order to pursue their views.

The guy isn’t crazy though. He just did what he deemed necessary, how horrible it might be.

But it is not something a sane person would/should ever do, isn’t that the definition of crazy?
[/quote]Last time i checked, being crazy involved making hasty irrational decisions, neither of which would fit into Breiviks profile.[/quote]
MITB is right, the definition of crazy could include Breivik because his view on the world is so different than rest of us.
He wouldn’t get prison sentence then, but he would still be locked up, and the chance of being locked up for the rest of his life is greater. Since he would never be normal.

item.title: Terror in the capital of peace (76? deaths)
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:138, topic:405764”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=502755.msg3704727#msg3704727 date=1312951677]

I did forget about the amazingly long sentences spent on death row in US prisons. Do they get the same access to resources to appeal on death row? I don’t really know much about it.

Unfortunately yes, they can appeal a ridiculous amount of times on the taxpayer’s dime, so in some states they end up spending 20+ years on death row before they are actually killed, if they don’t die of old age first. They need to go back to the way it used to be, where you are sentenced to death, then hung that day or the next.
[/quote]And then hope to god he wasnt really innocent rite

Hopefully if you sentence someone to life in prison they aren’t innocent either.

That’s what the justice system is for, it leans heavily towards innocence (innocent until proven guilty), and someone is only found guilty if all 12 members of a jury of peers has absolutely no shred of reasonable doubt that they are guilty. If that’s true, they are guilty.

Now people will quote statistics of people sentenced and later exonerated after proving they were wrongly convicted, but pretty much all of those were cases from the early 90s and before where DNA testing wasn’t available at the time, but now that it is used everywhere, those mistakes don’t happen anymore.[/quote]Fair enough, time will tell i guess!

Read full topic
item.source: Terror in the capital of peace (76? deaths)

item.title: Terror in the capital of peace (76? deaths)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:137, topic:405764”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=502755.msg3704634#msg3704634 date=1312947836]

I did forget about the amazingly long sentences spent on death row in US prisons. Do they get the same access to resources to appeal on death row? I don’t really know much about it.

Unfortunately yes, they can appeal a ridiculous amount of times on the taxpayer’s dime, so in some states they end up spending 20+ years on death row before they are actually killed, if they don’t die of old age first. They need to go back to the way it used to be, where you are sentenced to death, then hung that day or the next.
[/quote]And then hope to god he wasnt really innocent rite[/quote]
Hopefully if you sentence someone to life in prison they aren’t innocent either.

That’s what the justice system is for, it leans heavily towards innocence (innocent until proven guilty), and someone is only found guilty if all 12 members of a jury of peers has absolutely no shred of reasonable doubt that they are guilty. If that’s true, they are guilty.

Now people will quote statistics of people sentenced and later exonerated after proving they were wrongly convicted, but pretty much all of those were cases from the early 90s and before where DNA testing wasn’t available at the time, but now that it is used everywhere, those mistakes don’t happen anymore.

Read full topic
